conclusion: Calculate the work done by the frictional force on the object as it moves from point M to point N on the conveyor belt.
The object is placed on a conveyor belt moving at constant speed v = 6 m/s. The frictional force between the object and the belt will do work on the object.
The frictional force is given by F_friction = μ · m · g.
μ = 0.3 is the coefficient of kinetic friction, m = 3 kg is the mass of the object, g = 10 m/s² is the acceleration due to gravity.
Calculate the frictional force: F_friction = 0.3 · 3 kg · 10 m/s² = 9 N.
Work done by a force is given by W = F · d · cos(θ).
F is the magnitude of the force, d is the distance over which the force acts, θ is the angle between the force and the direction of motion.
The frictional force acts in the opposite direction to the motion of the object, so θ = 180° and cos(180°) = -1.
The distance d between points M and N is L₁ = 10 m.
Calculate the work done: W = 9 N · 10 m · (-1) = -90 J.
The negative sign indicates that the work done by the frictional force is in the opposite direction to the motion of the object.
Friction is removing energy from the system, slowing down the object relative to the conveyor belt.
The work done by the frictional force of the conveyor belt on the object as it is transported from point M to point N is -90 J.
